meta.description: Episode 8: Duel. The Liberator holeds up around an apparently dead planet, after fleeing the Federation. Travis attacks, but is stopped by magic space magic and Blake and Travis are forced to do battle in a woodland. Blake has the help of Jenna, Travis his Mutoid pilot. Blake wins but chooses not to kill Travis for solid, practical reasons.

content.p: In the last episode, Avon and Cally got to play at Sherlock Holmes in a haunted house stricken spaceship. It had quite a complicated plot with red herrings and McGuffins. This time, Blake and Travis go to a wood and hit each other with sticks.

figure.figcaption: Can anyone else hear Bonnie Tyler?

content.p: The episode starts with a of Sinofar, The Guardian, appearing among some polystyrene rocks as part of some strange ceremony on a semi-dead planetThe planet's also got some lovely foggy woodland.. There are VIDEO EFFECTS. So much video effects. Sinofar's outfit has been designed with the Dad demographic in mind.

Giroc, The Keeper, comes shuffling on set, dressed in hessian and carrying a staff. Jesus, what a mess. There's a lot of balls about The Power and Balance, but the upshot seems to be that both of them have some powers which they didn't choose and are obliged to remain on the planet for ... reasons.

ross.p: When I first saw this episode, I was in that brief, blissful period in a gynephilic's life when breasts had ceased to be nourishment, but had yet to become arousing. I was probably greatly relieved to be back in the cold embrace of space.

figure.figcaption: Travis' brand new Starburst Class ships (the previous generation of ships were called the Opal Fruits Class)

content.p: Finally, we're in ruddy space. We get to see Travis' new Starbust class ships, which he ordered from Servalan during Seek-Locate-Destroy. Travis is excited because he's finally tracked down Blake.

The Liberator is looking for somewhere to recharge and take stock, as they've been fleeing Federation ships and their power banks are all run down. Avon calculatesUsing a normal, 1978 calculator that they need 48 hours to recharge.

Blake, Jenna and Gan want to go down the planet to stretch their legs. Vila and Avon are staying behind and Cally is nowhere to be seen. She's probably doing some telepathy in her room. Vila has to squeeze past Avon, in order to operate the teleporter so Avon squares up to him, seemingly for his own entertainment.
Back on Travis' ship, his Mutoid needs to change her blood serum vial. We learn that they're sort of vampires.

ross.p: I might be reading too much into this, but the scene where the Mutoid changes her blood serum seems to be disturbing on a number of levels. Travis uses the word coyness, when the Mutoid admits she wouldn't usually change the vial in front of an unmodified.

The shape and size of the vessel, plus the use of the word blood suggest menstruation, which would have been almost as big a taboo as Vampirism in the in 1978Indeed advertising sanitary products on television was only made legal in the 1980s, but I can't seem to find the date when this actually happened. Perhaps I've finally found something which is too niche for the Internet: the history of sanitary products advertising in the .. I wonder if Terry Nation wasn't using to say something subversive about ourI have no idea who this our refers to. discomfort with the menstrual cycle.

char.p: So I've just recalled that in Destiny of the Daleks, also written by Mr Nation, the Movellans had to recharge by changing their tubes. They were (spoiler) robots not vampires, but it does seem as though Terry had a thing for Tampax themed energy packs. Subtle feminist messaging? Or perhaps just shoddy plot recycling...

figure.figcaption: It's supposed to be a broken weapon.

content.p: Jenna, Blake and Gan turn up at the location used in the opening scene. Gan spots Sinofar and Giroc and tries to alert Blake, but the women have hidden behind a rock, or something. He thinks his 's on the blink. Gan finds a statue of some dude running a relay race.
Gan spots Travis' fleet in the sky, using the Mark One Eyeball, so Blake raises the alarm and Vila teleports them back. Sinofar and Giroc get popcorn.

The Liberator doesn't have enough power to escape, and barely enough power to fight. Blake asks Zen what the battle computers think, and they suggest surrenderThis is like using Google, and it telling you to get outside and go for a nice walk.. The pursuit ships whittle away at Blake's power with plasma bolts but Blake works out that the one ship which hasn't fired must be Travis, so plans to ram it. Before the ships collide, some sort of space magic stops them from working and we get another . It goes on for ages and it really wants to be the stargate sequence from 2001 when it grows up.
Giroc speaks to both crews and explains that they cannot use their ships then poofs Blake and Travis down to the planet. Sinofar and Giroc introduce themselves, so let's do that:

biog.info: Wise alien archetype, exciter of Dads

info.type: Structural model of the psyche component

ross.p: There's no polite way to say this but during the scene, Sinofar is crying out for bra. Come on, dear. You'll catch your death.

info.type: Structural model of the psyche component

ross.p: I like that Giroc is an old woman who doesn't conform to any stereotypes: she adores violence and insults Travis' stupidity loudly and often. I think people often assume that affirmative action or political correctness means we need to portray minorities in a positive light. I disagree: any non-stereotypical depiction is enough.

content.h2: Let's settle this the old fashioned way
content.p: Their planet was in a state of constant war until it went nuclear and everyone died. Sinofar's plan is to get Travis and Blake to fight each other, in order to save the lives of their crew members who would have died, had they had their nice space battle. But she also wants them to understand what it's like to lose a loved one, so she takes one crew member from each ship to fight alongside themBlake seems to recognise this as the prisoner's dilemma, and says to Travis We could agree not to fight. Travis ain't interested..
Sinofar poofs Blake into a foggy wood with a sword. Giroc uses some magic to cause Blake pain, for some reason. It looks like thisThere wasn't such a thing as strobe lighting warnings in 1978.:

Then she brings Travis in, who's very sporting, and gives Blake a chance to recover, when he could have just stabbed him up. Travis is just about to cut Blake's throat when Sinofar is all nope!, and restarts the contest. Giroc likes a bit of a rumble, see, where as Sinofar is all about TEACHING THESE PEOPLE LESSONS.

content.h2: Explore the world through someone else's eyes.
content.p: The crew of The Liberator get to watch the whole thing on their view-screen. But before Blake goes boom-boom behind a tree with his crew all watching through their fingers, he bumps into Jenna, who tells him about the live feed. Blake starts sharpening some sticks, just like kids would do in the woods, when given half a chance.
Travis gets his Mutoid pilot gal-pal:

biog.info: The Mutoid previously known as Keyeira

info.type: Favourite thing about being a mutoid

biog.info: The rainproof headgear, plus the medical insurance perks.

content.p: They do some talking in front of a chroma key screen. Just as Blake predicted, Travis plans to set a trap. Cally, watching from The Liberator thinks that Travis is making a mistake, by setting a trap: That sort of war is best fought on the moveI like this, because it gives us insight into Cally's guerrilla warfare days..

Night falls and the stock sound effects suggest (but don't show) that there are large, frightening creatures in the woods. Travis and his Mutoid have constructed a sort of spiky frame. Travis talks to his Mutoid about her previous life but she is beyond uninterested in the conversation. He tries to upset her, by talking about who she was, before she was surgically transformed into a Mutoid, but she is so indifferent, he gives up and falls asleep.
In the morning, Travis finds a number of bats at the foot of the tree. His Mutoid trapped them and drank their blood, because she's metal .

Blake climbs a tree to try and spot Travis. Jenna hears the Mutoid rustling about and goes after her. She is immediately captured and tied up then the Mutoid extends a needle toward Jenna's neck, so she can drink her blood. Travis stops her, for some reason. Perhaps he's squeamish.

Travis shouts to Blake, asking him to give himself up. Blake spots Jenna, tied up next to a tree. He approaches her and Travis bellows Now!. Suspended above him is Travis' rickety frame of spiky death. The Mutoid hacks away at the rope holding it aloft, but Jenna and Blake escape. While Jenna gets rid of her bonds, Travis and Blake have a stave fight. Then the Mutoid arrives, and Jenna and her have a fight too. Blake wins his fight, but refuses to kill Travis, despite Cally's telepathic goading. Avon shakes his head, while smiling to himself. Clearly, he predicted this outcome.
Blake explains to Giroc why he didn't kill Travis: if he had Travis would be replaced. And Blake knows he can beat Travis.

ross.p: This is a small twist. Usually, this kind of story goes one of a few ways:

ul.li: Omnipotent beings teach the protagonist something, which the antagonist refuses to learn
The protagonist teaches the omnipotent being something, and raises their opinion of humanity in the process
We (the audience) learn something about the protagonist and the antagonist, in the means by which they do battle

li.q: The power was inside you all along

ul.li: (Of the creature the protagonist is forced to fight) We are not so different, you and I

ross.p: While we do learn about Blake and TravisFor example, for all Travis' claims to Servalan that he wants to work with Mutoids for their cold efficiency, he's disappointed that his Mutoid doesn't get riled up, when he talks about her previous life., Blake doesn't refuse to kill Travis for moral reasons, or because that would make him what he hates. He refuses to kill Travis out of utility: because he thinks he's better at this than Travis is.
I like this, because it avoids Star Trek's smug sense of moral superiority.

content.p: The Liberator gets a full charge, and pulls away.

The Mutoid is dead, having run out of blood. Sinofar offers to return her to life, but Travis is like whatevs, then demands to go back to his ship. Sinofar restores her life anyway. Travis plans to subject her to court martial, because she didn't cut the rope fast enough. The mutoid suggests that if she'd been allowed to drink Jenna's blood, she'd have been right as rain. Silly Travis.
Travis sets a course to follow Blake.
